text: and specifically the the thing that that
we got into the Oregon bill that was
negotiated out of the previous bills in
California and elsewhere was a ban on
Parts pairing which is um Apple's uh new
invention this is Parts pairing is not
something you you encounter unless
you're trying to fix an iPhone really um
it's it's a new idea uh that is hey you
know we have software in all of the
individual part so there's not just
software on the mainboard there's
software in the camera there's software
on in the display and so why not have a
serial number in the display and that
serial number can be hardcoded into the
main board and the main board will only
work with that display or it'll degrade
functionality if it's not the serial
number that it's expecting uh and you
know in the software world you look at
this like if I was to ask you hey build
me a lock that does this you're like
okay sure it'll be done tomorrow like
this is not a hard lock to build um but
it's really nefarious because once you
once you have these parts all paired to
each other now it totally impedes what
you can do it doesn't just limit the
repairs that you can do yourself what
happens if if you donate your phone to
Goodwill and Goodwill get you know
they've got two broken iPhones and they
want to take the pieces and combine it
and make one that that works and sell it
that's that's the business model that
all PC uh Recycling and and and
computers for schools Charities have
operated under for the last couple
decades and apple uh just shot it in the
head they said no you can't do that
anymore you have to have permission from
us in order to swap parts in the device
so that Parts pairing approach has been
Apple has been turning the temperature
up on that slowly we published a chart
which shows Parts pairing really
starting with the the fingerprint sensor
in the iPhone 6s and then every model
they've added it to more and more parts
uh with the with the iPhone 15 they
added it to the lar sensors so you can't
swap the Lars between devices and so we
published this chart it was a huge issue
uh you know we detailed the the parts
pairing progression New York Times
actually thought it was so interesting
that they ran it in their like Sunday
print issue right around the time the
new iPhone came out when we when we
analyzed the 15 and the fall uh and that
set the stage for the legislative fight
which is always at the beginning of the
year that's when the state legislators
get together and and figure out what
laws they're going to pass for the year
and we have a number of states that're
looking at at bans on Parts pairing the
Oregon bill is the first one to get over
the finish line and apple does not like
this law at all they they were in behind
the scenes and and actually they kind of
finally popped out in front and
testified against it um they threw
everything they could at stopping this
uh and we were able to overcome them so
feel very good about it uh but what a
nefarious strategy why would you do that
